Posts.Content: While we're waiting for Mark's results.....this is my first post. I went for a regular blood screen in May (vitamin/diet doctor) and my PSA came back at 17.7 from Quest diagnostics lab! I'm 58 years old and my father had prostate cancer in his mid 70s (successfully treated with proton therapy at Loma Linda). I made quick pace to a urologist. DRE was normal. Another PSA with his lab came back 24.6! Two weeks of antibiotics (levo), wait two weeks, another PSA came back 28.9! MRI ordered and no signs of anything spreading with just one spot of an "indeterminate abnormality". Biopsy is scheduled for August 14th. He'll take 16 samples, or "until my wrist gets tired" (my doc has a sense of humor). I'll let you guys know what's up...obviously could be a few different things. I just wanted to share and thank everyone for their honest remarks on this forum. It's a huge help. Good luck to everyone!
Posts.Title: PSA 28.9, Biopsy Coming Soon

Posts.Content: Thanks for the special treatment! What confounds the urologist is that the DRE was so normal and that I have no symptoms at all. With a PSA that high, he would expect burning, pain, difficulty urinating, etc. but I have none of that. As I mentioned, I only found this while checking on cholesterol and glucose! My last PSA was ten years ago and that was a 1.3. To add to this, I take finesteride for hair and from what I've read that can falsely bring down a reading, so it might otherwise be even higher?

Posts.Content: Hi--I don't see a Sticky for what I need to know about Proton Therapy? Is there one? What I'm looking for is PT vs EBRT...the RO I spoke to the other day says there is no difference. Another said that PT is just radiation therapy for the wealthy. What do you guys think or know? Thank you as always! This is a great forum.
Posts.Signature: Age 58 DRE Normal BIOPSY 8/14/2018 T1C diagnosis Gleason 4+3=7 PSA 25 RMB, Prostatic Adenocarcinoma, Grade Group 3, involving 10% of one (1) core, Length of cancer 1.5mm Tumor focally in contact with extraprostatic extension LMA: Rare atypical glands suspicious for carcinoma Focal chronic inflammation in RMA, LLM, LMM Mild chronic inflammation RLB Bone/CT Scan Negative
